author: slarti
title: Making Cardano the go to for games
description: How can game developers, especially indie developers, access and easily implement a payment system, circumventing the big payment providers?

assessments.note: valid idea, backed by no meaningful details of how to achieve it.

I believe that the idea presented has potential, but as there is no description of a plan, it is not possible to assess how the proposal will address the challenge.

I recommend that the proposer see the proposals related to NFTs that are being created in Catalyst, since some of these proposals contain similarities that can help in the construction of the idea or to form partnerships with other people interested in the game market.

Whilst an "easy toolset" might help adoption of the Cardano protocol, the proposal does not explain anything about the "easy toolset" to be funded. When they would be developed, presumably by the proposer. Perhaps this would be more interesting if developed for a later funding round with more specifics.

I can see where this can potentially develop into - but at the present stage there is very little material to work with. It is a very bare bones idea without actual merits per se that would warrant investing presently. Gaming is very important adoption venue but it does require more in depth analysis from the author to understand how this aligns with goals of the community at large and where their proposal ticks all the boxes.

There is no reasonable plan and there is not enough detail about the proposer's professional experience. I recommend that the proposal be described according to the Catalyst guidelines and that the proposer provide details about his professional experience, skills and link to Github / Linkedin.
Actually no plan has been presented.

There is no information that would meaningfully allow us to review this proposal at this stage. It lacks basic elements of relevant experience validity (any external links to sources or past work) nor does it explain in any depth what and why this budget is something to be desired. Adding these elements are crucial in order to be better next time.
none are provided. high fund request with no justification.
There is not enough information to indicate the feasibility of the proposal and how it will address the challenge in an impactful way.

As stated above, the proposal contains no information other than the solution statement that would suggest how the funds would be spent to accomplish the objective, and how the tools would be monetised (open source, free or at a cost)

Proposal has no elements of roadmap or milestones that could help envision where and how it is headed in which direction. Also - adding in the future some definition of success measured in metrics/KPIs be really useful. I would also like authors to think about how they approach any challenges/risks associated with their proposal (if any). This additional information would help clarify the direction of this proposal not only for community who would be interested in funding but also authors knowing what needs to be done. I suggest to resubmit at the later stage with more details.

The idea of the proposal is in line with the challenge, but there are not enough details to assess the impact of the proposal, I believe it is important to provide more information and data on the problem, a "commission" of 30% of the app stores was mentioned, but I think that providing data to corroborate the statement and enrich the proposal is important for the community to make an informed decision. Besides, how big is this market? and what is the volume of transactions in that market?
Idea is good and much needed but I believe Charles has already been planning for this kind of app store in depth. I think its too early for this proposal to be taking place.

Potentially a good use case - but proposal is very thin in tackling in greater detail how it all ties to cardano mission and how community would benefit from pursuing it. Adding more information into the mix would make that easier to decipher. I suggest reworking the concept and coming back in later rounds.

There is no detailed plan and the proposer's description of experience lacks details, I think it is important for the proposer to report previous experiences, if there will be more people involved in the proposal, his ability to develop smart contracts and I recommend the inclusion of a link to Github and Linkedin .
Experience is noted but vague. More details would ve great in what role you would play in the creation of this idea. Is there a team? How would costs look like?

This is a very bare bone concept. It needs a lot more in depth information to make it considered for funding. Things like budget that would actually break down into various categories. We need to understand how the requested figure is going to be used and help achieve the goal. Because this is just an idea - there is no actual plan in place. Hence we can't even determine validity of it feasibility. Also - adding professional links, references would make it easier to learn about those going to implement these suggestions.

There is no roadmap, milestones, KPIs, details about budget allocation and details about the proposer's professional experience. I recommend including and detailing this information so that we can understand the feasibility of the proposal and better understand how it will address the challenge in a relevant way.

General lack of detail here to know what sort of deliverables could be achieved. A roadmap would be a next step to think about in my opinion. I think the idea needs to be narrowed down from where it currently is.

Proposal is in concept stage. Meaning there are missing elements of actual roadmap, milestones, success metrics, talks about potential challenges, risks. All of that would elevate this proposal a lot. I suggest joining mentorship program in Catalyst and see if some work can be curated with their help. At the moment - not investable.

solution: Providing an easy toolset, accessible through asset store like under Unity development platform and providing the payment service.
experience: Over 25 years experience in programming, financial and computer science studies.
